ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: you learn a lot about genocide

This class provided me with valuable comparative skills. By looking at a (very) wide range of genocides across time, the class was able to simultaneously analyze broad themes and nuances between cases.
I learnt genocidal events from ancient time till today. Throughout the course, I get to know how to do comparative studies and how to conduct a research about genocide.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is perfectly organized. The readings are set in a chronological way, which helps us understand the topics in a systematic way. Moreover, we have guest speakers and serial conferences, which helps us know the latest research.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure! Prof Kiernan is super kind. He knows how to guide students to conduct research! And the course is really interesting. I can always find inspirations when listening to his interpretation and his questions in class.
